thread.title: school football | Hilliard Davidson rolls over Olentangy Liberty
thread.title_full: High-school football | Hilliard Davidson rolls over Olentangy Liberty | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: school football | Hilliard Davidson rolls over Olentangy Liberty
text:
One of the biggest thrills for grade-school kids after a Hilliard Davidson victory is to run through a gantlet of players in the end zone while his or her name is being chanted.
It’s all about community and having fun.
Olentangy Liberty also was smothered on Friday night, but it was because it was another brick in the road leading to an Ohio Capital Conference Central Division championship for the Wildcats.
>> Videos | Football highlights from around central Ohio
>> High-school football results, box scores from Week 8
In a 26-0 victory, Davidson was at its bruising best in intercepting a pass, recovering a fumble for a touchdown, coming up with four sacks and stopping the Patriots on downs four times.
The Wildcats (7-1, 5-0) clinched at least a tie for the division championship and also solidified their chances of making the Division I playoffs for the eighth straight season. Coach Brian White does not preach revenge but said the team never forgot how it got knocked around during a 21-0 loss to Liberty in 2014.
“We talked about that all week long because they physically pounded us,” White said. “That was as sound a defeat as we’ve had in a long time. Being physical, that’s our style.”
White said it also helped that Liberty senior quarterback Alex Lando did not play because of an injured right throwing shoulder he suffered last week against Westland. Senior Corbin Rapier started.
Few quarterbacks could have mounted much against Davidson, especially after it took a 12-0 lead on 16- and 15-play touchdown drives on its first two possessions. The Wildcats converted four third downs on the first drive. Ryan Royer scored on a 2-yard run.
Royer, who ran for 143 yards on 30 carries, said the players were determined to make up for last season’s loss.
“I remember they were so much more physical than us,” he said. “They dominated us. We couldn’t get anything going offensively, defensively and on special teams. We had the mind-set that we wanted to win so badly. Hilliard Davidson football is hard-nosed.”
On their second possession, the Wildcats converted on fourth-and-1 at their 18-yard line on a 3-yard run by Royer. Two third downs also were converted before quarterback Jack Klein ran for a 1-yard touchdown.
Davidson’s defense never let the Patriots (6-2, 3-2) get into any kind of rhythm. It held on downs at its 15 and 35 in the second quarter, its 32 in the third quarter and at midfield in the fourth.
Defensive lineman Dylan Day was in the middle of things with two sacks and by falling on the ball in the end zone for a touchdown after a snap went over Rapier’s head.
“We just tried to get after them with our front four,” Day said. “We wanted to stop the running game first because that got them struggling off the bat. Getting stops gets our offense going. It keeps the ball out of their hands.”
The outcome was all but sealed after defensive back Tyler Lomphoy made a diving interception at the Liberty 12-yard line with 1:52 left in the third quarter.
Three plays later, Royer scored on a 7-yard run around right end to make it 19-0.
Offensive lineman Kyle Bessen said the players are playing for one another.
“We’d do anything for each other,” he said. “We’ve developed chemistry. We’re always around each other. We’re playing as a unit. We’re coming together.”
mznidar@dispatch.com
@MarkZnidar
